item.title: Macron Insists Europe Remains Central to Global Stability
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron, speaking at the Munich Security Conference, stressed European “fortitude.” Earlier, Chancellor Friedrich Merz of Germany criticized President Trump’s rapid reorientation of U.S. foreign policy.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Tarique Rahman Is Elected Bangladesh’s New Leader
item.description: Tarique Rahman, the scion of a political dynasty, returned to sweep his party into government with a promise of change. Some have doubts.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das, Saif Hasnat and Lam Yik Fei
item.media:description: Tarique Rahman in his office in Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Tuesday.

item.title: UK Ban on Palestine Action Is Unlawful, Court Finds
item.description: The High Court said the ban on Palestine Action as a terrorist group was disproportionate and breached free speech rights. The government said it would appeal, and the ban remained in place for now.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Supporters of Palestine Action protesting on Friday outside the Royal Court of Justice in London.

item.title: Venezuelan Politician Living in Exile in the US is Detained by ICE
item.description: Carlos Roberto García, an ex-mayor opposed to the Maduro regime, fled Venezuela in 2017. He faces deportation to a country with a long history of punishing political dissidents.
item.dc:creator: Luis Ferré-Sadurní, Patricia Sulbarán and Isayen Herrera

item.title: Amid Fallout From Epstein Files, Dubai’s DP World Boss Is Replaced
item.description: Sultan Ahmed bin Sulayem was credited with turning the state-backed DP World into a global logistics powerhouse. He was recently identified in correspondence with Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Sultan Ahmed bin Sulayem in 2022. He was identified this week in files related to Mr. Epstein.

item.title: Bangladeshis Vote in Droves for Constitutional Change in Referendum
item.description: Eight out of 10 voters backed reforms intended to safeguard democracy and increase women’s participation in politics.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das and Saif Hasnat
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Checking election results at the Bangladesh Election Commission building in Dhaka on Friday.

item.title: Heated Rivalry and Marital Bliss: Two Wives Go Head to Head in a Scary Olympic Sport
item.description: One represents Belgium and the other Brazil in skeleton, in which the racer slides near-blind down an ice track at well over 80 miles per hour.
item.dc:creator: Heather Knight and James Hill
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: Nicole Silveira of Brazil, left, and Kim Meylemans of Belgium, a married couple, are competing against each other, but they also have their own unit: Team BB.

item.title: 2 ISIS Supporters Who Planned Attack on Jews in U.K. Get Life Sentences
item.description: The case underlines how the Islamic State has seized on rising antisemitism in the wake of the Gaza war to radicalize and encourage would-be assailants.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: A surveillance image released by the Greater Manchester Police shows Walid Saadaoui, 38, right, and Amar Hussein, 52, left, near Dover, southern England, in May.

item.title: Milan Has an Affordable Housing Crisis. Can the Olympic Village Help?
item.description: The accommodation for athletes includes a video game lounge, massage room and a range of food options. Starting from September, it will house students — or at least those who can afford the rent.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:description: The Olympic Village complex in Milan. The village’s developer has touted it as a great gift to the city that will provide 6 percent of the beds needed for students.

item.title: Ukraine Says U.S. Is Increasing Pressure for a Deal as the Midterms Loom
item.description: It is unclear what the Trump administration is prepared to do if it does not get the concessions it wants from Kyiv on issues like territory and elections.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:description: An artillery unit of the Ukrainian Army preparing to fire at Russian positions near Pokrovsk, Ukraine, in December.

item.title: Japan Seizes Chinese Fishing Boat; Move Likely to Add to Tensions
item.description: The seizure of the trawler, which Japan said was sailing in its waters in the East China Sea, is likely to add to tensions between Tokyo and Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:credit: Fisheries Agency Of Japan, via Reuters
item.media:description: A photo released by Japan’s Fisheries Agency shows a Japanese patrol vessel, left, and a Chinese fishing boat off the coast of Nagasaki on Thursday.

item.title: Europe’s Leaders Gather At Munich Summit, Reeling From Trump’s Criticism
item.description: Officials gather on Friday for Europe’s biggest annual security summit, where a speech by Vice President JD Vance last year started an unraveling of trans-Atlantic relations.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: Vice President JD Vance speaking at the Munich Security Conference last year.

item.title: Canada School Shooter’s Online Life Showed Interest in Violent Extremism
item.description: The suspect in the British Columbia shooting had long been posting about mental health problems, substance abuse and a fascination with weapons and online violence.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Aric Toler, Pranav Baskar, Malachy Browne, Amy Harmon and Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Alana Paterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The family home where the authorities say Jesse Van Rootselaar killed her mother, Jennifer Jacobs, and her brother, Emmett Jacobs.

item.title: Do Drug Cartels Actually Use Drones at the Border?
item.description: U.S. officials warn that cartel-operated drones on the border pose a major threat. Mexican officials are less certain. Analysts say the answer is likely in between.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Paulina Villegas
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: The border wall between Mexico and the United States in Tijuana, Mexico.

item.title: How Peter Biar Ajak, a Sudanese Peace Activist, Was Caught Plotting a Coup
item.description: Peter Biar Ajak, a democracy advocate, was convicted of conspiring to buy and export weapons for a revolt in South Sudan.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Peter Biar Ajak after returning to the United States in 2020. A federal court in Arizona sentenced him to prison last week after he pleaded guilty to conspiring to violate U.S. weapons export laws.

item.title: New Research Absolves the Woman Blamed for a Dynasty’s Ruin
item.description: A Chinese king’s infatuation with a woman was seen as the reason that a golden age collapsed. Evidence suggests climate change and internal strife played bigger roles.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Researchers digging to unearth remnants of what is believed to have been a fortified gate guarding an entrance to the capital of the Western Zhou dynasty, near Hejia Village, China, in December.

item.title: First U.S. Troops Land in Nigeria for Trump-Led Christian Mission
item.description: The deployment follows months of escalating pressure from President Trump on the African nation, including a surprise missile strike on Christmas Day.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean, Eric Schmitt and Ismail Alfa
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on ISIS in Nigeria (2025- )
item.media:description: A damaged door frame at a church in Nigeria, where worshipers were kidnapped after being attacked by gunmen, in Kurmin Wali, Kaduna, last month.

item.title: Ilia Malinin’s catastrophic free skate: ‘I blew it.’
item.description: Malinin, the heavy favorite to win gold, fell twice during his final routine and finished 8th.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather, Doug Mills and Vincent Alban

item.title: U.N. Condemns U.S. Measures Halting Oil Deliveries to Cuba
item.description: The measures were installed last month by the Trump administration after the U.S. captured Nicolás Maduro and seized control of Venezuela’s oil industry.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A street in Santa Cruz del Norte, Cuba, this month during a scheduled outage as part of energy rationing.

item.title: Trump’s ‘Board of Peace’ Said to Raise Billions in First Pledges for Gaza
item.description: The United Arab Emirates and the United States have each committed more than $1 billion to President Trump’s new international initiative, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Natan Odenheimer
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children collecting paper and plastic at a garbage dump in Gaza last month. Vast sections of the territory were destroyed in the war.

item.title: The Mutually Beneficial Ties Between Jeffrey Epstein and Thorbjorn Jagland
item.description: Thorbjorn Jagland, a former prime minister of Norway who led the Nobel Committee, promised influence, and the disgraced financier had gifts to give, new emails show.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Henrik Pryser Libell
item.media:description: Thorbjorn Jagland, center left, a former prime minister of Norway, in Oslo on Thursday. A recently released tranche of emails revealed his friendship with Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: At Munich Summit, European Leaders Agree With Trump: The Old World Order Is Over
item.description: At the Munich Security Conference, U.S. officials softened their tone but not their message: Europe should pay its own way. European leaders increasingly agree.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, Chancellor Friedrich Merz of Germany and Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain at the Munich Security Conference on Friday.

item.title: Germany’s leader says his country is in discussions with France on a European nuclear deterrent.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France and Chancellor Friedrich Merz of Germany at an informal E.U. leaders’ retreat in Belgium on Thursday.

item.title: Macron urges Europe to step up on the global stage and stresses unity on major issues, particularly Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, in remarks at the Munich Security Conference on Friday, implicitly warned the United States not to exclude Europe from talks on security guarantees for Ukraine.

item.title: Can’t Buy Love? Kenya Bans Bouquets Made of Cash.
item.description: Floral arrangements crafted from carefully-folded, colorful bank notes, had become a popular symbol of love in Nairobi.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Brian O. Otieno and Ed Ram
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Ed Ram for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cash bouquet.

item.title: How Bangladesh Went From Revolution to Elections
item.description: Bangladesh held the first national elections since a student revolution in the summer of 2024. Standing outside the Dhaka university, the epicenter of the student movement, New York Times correspondent Anupreeta Das explains what the recent elections mean for the country’s future.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das, Katrin Bennhold, Leila Medina, James Surdam, Parin Behrooz and Lam Yik Fei

item.title: Key Moments in Gisèle Pelicot’s Interview With The New York Times
item.description: The woman at the center of France’s largest-ever mass-rape trial told us about her life before, during and after the abuse she suffered at the hands of her husband.
item.dc:creator: Lulu Garcia-Navarro
item.media:credit: Philip Gay for The New York Times

item.title: ’The Interview’: Gisèle Pelicot Shares Her Story
item.description: In her first interview with an American media outlet, Pelicot opens up about surviving years of secret abuse — and a trial that shocked the world.
item.dc:creator: Lulu Garcia-Navarro
item.media:credit: Philip Gay for The New York Times

item.title: As Diplomats Talk, Pentagon Prepares for Possible War With Iran
item.description: President Trump threatened to strike Iran, but the military has needed time to build up its forces in the region.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: People in Tehran walk on U.S. and Israeli flags during a march to commemorate the 47th anniversary of Iran’s Islamic revolution. Senior officials said Mr. Trump had not decided whether he would strike Iran.

item.title: German Officials Needle Trump at Munich Security Conference
item.description: Friedrich Merz, the chancellor of Germany, said that under President Trump, the United States’ claim to global leadership “has been challenged, and possibly squandered.”
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: Chancellor Friedrich Merz of Germany speaking at the Munich Security Conference, on Friday.

item.title: U.S. Transfers Thousands of ISIS Prisoners to Iraq From Syria
item.description: The moves appear to highlight lingering doubts in Washington about the new Syrian government’s ability to ensure security.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: U.S. military vehicles in Qamishli, Syria, escorted buses transporting Islamic State detainees to Iraq this month.

item.title: A nervous Europe awaits Rubio’s speech in Munich.
item.description: After a fiery speech by Vice President JD Vance turned heads in 2026, Europeans are nervous about what the Secretary of State might say.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio arriving in Munich on Friday.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler, Jim Tankersley, Aurelien Breeden and Richard Pérez-Peña

item.title: Why India Playing Pakistan in World Cup Cricket Matters
item.description: The cricket-mad South Asian neighbors have a bitter history, punctuated by violence and wars. It makes this one of the fiercest, and most financially lucrative, rivalries in sports.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado and Pragati K.B.
item.media:description: The cricket rivalry between India and Pakistan is one of the fiercest in any sport in the world.

item.title: Iran Turns to Digital Surveillance Tools to Track Down Protesters
item.description: As Iranian authorities restore some online services after crushing antigovernment demonstrations, they are using a technological dragnet to target attendees of the protests.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano, Paul Mozur and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Antigovernment protesters blocked a road last month in Tehran. Iran is using facial recognition and phone data to track and detain people involved in political opposition activities.

item.title: Ex-Leader of Norway Charged With Corruption Linked to Epstein
item.description: Thorbjorn Jagland, who briefly led Norway in the 1990s, had been protected by diplomatic immunity that came with his work with the Council of Europe, but that privilege was waived.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Stian Lysberg Solum/NTB Scanpix, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Thorbjorn Jagland, center left, a former prime minister of Norway, in Oslo on Thursday.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.description: The Bangladesh Nationalist Party, led by Tarique Rahman, swept to victory on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das and Saif Hasnat

item.title: Ontario Lifts Tuition Freeze at Public Universities
item.description: The move will allow the schools to raise tuition for the first time since 2019 as part of a broader plan to boost funding for higher education in the Canadian province.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Students at the St. George Campus of the University of Toronto, Canada, last year.

item.title: How Europe Woke Up to Trump
item.description: European leaders are wondering if they can ever trust the U.S. again.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: Trump in Davos last month.

item.title: Chloe Kim, once a teenage phenom, loses to a new one.
item.description: Kim was upset in heavy snow by a new star, 17-year-old, Choi Gaon of South Korea, in the women’s halfpipe.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather and Gabriela Bhaskar

item.title: Israeli Army Reservists Are Suspected of Using Inside Knowledge to Bet
item.description: The authorities said several reservists and a civilian were arrested, and two were charged, after an investigation into the use of classified information to bet on military operations.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli military vehicles in a staging area near the border with Lebanon in 2024. Israeli reservists are accused of using classified information to place bets.

item.title: El Niño May Be Back This Summer, Bringing Drought and Floods
item.description: The powerful weather pattern is expected to shift into gear again around June, NOAA said, though its strength this time remains a question.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:description: A storm in California during the last El Niño phase, in 2023. The El Niño weather pattern has far-reaching influence.

item.title: Trump’s Actions Test the Fragile World of Air Travel
item.description: Last-minute announcements and abrupt changes by the Trump administration have caused confusion in an already strained U.S. aviation system.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi and Christine Chung
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: A nearly deserted security checkpoint at El Paso International Airport on Wednesday after the Federal Aviation Administration announced a 10-day ban on flights over the city.

item.title: What is Israel Doing in Africa?
item.description: The region has become a critical theater for global rivalries amid Israel’s recognition of breakaway Somaliland and Washington’s counterterrorism efforts.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: In Hargeisa, the capital of Somaliland, last year.

item.title: 4 Months Trapped in a Hospital for an Obsolete Way of Treating Their Disease
item.description: Health workers in developing countries know that isolating tuberculosis patients is an outdated and potentially harmful practice, but lack the resources to move away from it.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen and Arlette Bashizi
item.media:credit: Arlette Bashizi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Asta Djouma, a tuberculosis patient in isolation at the Djarengol Kodek Health Center in Maroua, northern Cameroon, who hasn’t seen her three children since she was admitted in October. “We’re just here,” she said.

item.title: Europe Worries Trump Poses Threat to Its Financial and Tech Sovereignty
item.description: European leaders have been compelled to address the possibility of once-remote risks to the financial networks and technology that undergird their economies.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen and Adam Satariano
item.media:description: The European Commission’s headquarters in Brussels. The Trump administration’s embrace of cryptocurrency has ratcheted up European concerns about control of the euro.

item.title: Dutch Prosecutors Fine Louis Vuitton Netherlands in Money Laundering Case
item.description: The Dutch subsidiary of the luxury brand agreed to pay a nearly $600,000 settlement in a money laundering and terrorism financing case.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses

item.title: Henry McGowan Found Not Guilty By Reason of Insanity in Father’s Murder
item.description: Henry McGowan of New York City was charged in the death of his father in an Irish hotel. He had struggled with mental illness for several years.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins

item.title: What We Know About the Victims of the Tumbler Ridge Mass Shooting in Canada
item.description: The attack at a secondary school and a private residence in the small, remote community in British Columbia has left families stunned and grief-stricken.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Vjosa Isai and Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Alana Paterson for The New York Times

item.title: From the chaos of snowboard cross, a repeat champ emerges.
item.description: Alessandro Hämmerle of Austria came from behind to win another gold medal in the men’s event.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather and Gabriela Bhaskar

item.title: NATO Remains Vital to U.S. Security, Ex-Ambassadors and Generals Say
item.description: Amid doubts over President Trump’s commitment to the alliance, an administration official told a NATO gathering that the U.S. is pulling back, but not abandoning European security.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Lara Jakes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A meeting of NATO defense ministers in Brussels on Thursday. The letter from the former U.S. officials was timed to the opening of the Munich Security Conference on Friday.

item.title: Across Italy, the Winter Olympic Vibes Are Very Different
item.description: In Milan, the hub of the Winter Games, the atmosphere seems subdued, while the small towns hosting mountain events are seeing enthusiastic crowds.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei, Tariq Panja, Heather Knight and Kim Severson
item.media:description: Spectators watched the Alpine skiing men’s super-G race from outside the Stelvio Ski Center in Bormio, Italy, on Wednesday.

item.title: These Ukrainian Drones Don’t Just Kill. They Deliver Oatmeal Cookies.
item.description: In a war where drones are synonymous with destruction, some are also used to drop care packages to Ukraine’s frontline soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Oleksandr Chubko and Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: Fruit and sweets being packed for soldiers on the front line.

item.title: Would You Leave Your Bag Unattended at a Starbucks? They Did. For Hours.
item.description: It is common for people to leave their belongings when they step away in South Korea. But some customers created a minor furor by occupying seats at a store without physically being there.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: Like many cafes and restaurants in South Korea, Starbucks does not prohibit customers from leaving personal belongings in their seats. But some go to extremes.

item.title: Ukrainian Olympian Is Disqualified Over Helmet Honoring War Dead
item.description: Olympic officials ruled that Vladyslav Heraskevych’s helmet violated a prohibition on political speech, setting off outrage at the Winter Games in Italy. He plans to appeal the decision.
item.dc:creator: Heather Knight and Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Ukraine’s Vladyslav Heraskevych was disqualified for wearing a helmet to commemorate athletes who were killed in the war with Russia.

item.title: Olympic Figure Skaters Are on Thin Ice Over Music Copyright Rules
item.description: Some Olympic athletes have found themselves caught up in controversies over musical choices before and during one of the biggest competitions of their careers.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: The Canadian ice dancing pair Zachary Lagha and Marjorie Lajoie performing on Saturday in Milan.

item.title: Turkish Nobel Novelist Orhan Pamuk Gets the Netflix Series He Wanted
item.description: After publishing more than 20 books and winning a Nobel Prize, the Turkish author fought to bring a celebrated novel to the screen — on his own terms.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Emin Ozmen
item.media:description: Orhan Pamuk in his office in Istanbul, in an apartment building named for his family.

item.title: Bangladesh Holds First Elections After 2024 Student Protests
item.description: At the vanguard of Gen Z movements, protesters in Bangladesh ousted the prime minister in 2024. They now face the hard reality of winning change through elections.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das, Saif Hasnat and Lam Yik Fei
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times

item.title: Top U.S. Energy Official Presses Venezuela to Do More to Spur Investment
item.description: Energy Secretary Chris Wright is one of the highest ranking American officials to visit Venezuela in nearly 30 years, marking warmer ties between Washington and Caracas.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amuay refinery, Venezuela’s largest, in Punto Fijo, Falcón state.
